author: holgerd77
content: Hey hey, qq, is the new ~16.78mio tx gas limit cap from EIP-7825 now also "automatically" the cap for an eth call, particularly in the context of an `eth_call` RPC call?

author: holgerd77
content:
Update: ok, now I am even more puzzled, we have this (pre-Osaka implementation) already defaulted to 0xffffff (so 16777215, which is one below the new cap ðŸ¤” ðŸ˜‹ ðŸ¤¯ ).

Not fully getting the pieces together yet.

author: pk910
content:
No, we've talked about this in a recent testing call I think.
The general consesnsus was to not apply this limit on eth_calls as it has no impact on the chain itself and is heavily used by UI components.
The "default" right now introduced by geth is at 50M gas per eth_call.  But it's actually up to client implementations. Still should be bigger than 16M at least ðŸ™‚

author: jochembrouwer
content: If we fork to Fusaka should the limit not be the exact limit (by default) as EIP-7825? Otherwise `eth_call` is performing invalid situations ðŸ¤” (Fine pre-Fusaka to set a high gas limit by default)

author: ben_a_adams
content: No; `eth_call` is used for all sorts of things; even gzip decompressing nft svgs and serving them as images

content: Hmm ok this is behavior I was not aware of ðŸ˜…

content: base64 encoded data: url; onchain zipped, then constructed by concatenating strings

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ahhh right of course, yes sorry. Makes total sense for those to indeed set a higher gas limit than accepted on chain ðŸ™‚
